Ochoa Industrial Sales Corporation is a chemical distributor located in Cata?o, Puerto Rico. Our business consist of buying and selling chemicasl for industrial customers in the island. We receive the materials included in this RMP already in their en use package. We donot repack them in our facility. The major risk that we have is the possibility of a package rupture during the forklift handlig. In order to prevent this possibility we have implemented a safety and security program in where we training our personnel in froklift operation, Hazardous Materials Handling and Warehouse safety.In order to address this issue we have prepared the following procedure:                                      PREVENTION, PREPAREDNESS, CONTINGENCY AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN
FOR THE WAREHOUSE FACILITIES OF OCHOA INDUSTRIAL SALES CORP.

1.0 Introduction

The information contained in this plan has been prepared in accordance with the requirements for a Prevention Preparedness and Contingency Plan as set forth in 40 CFR Parts 265.50 through 265.56, as well as any applicable Commonwealth of Puerto Rico laws, rules and regulations. Also, elements of Emergency Response Plans (in accordance to EPCRA requirements), and of Risk Management Plans (40 CFR 63) have been incorporated. The contents of this plan have been expanded to cover not only hazardous wastes but also hazardous materials present at the owner's facility.

This document constitutes the first revision to the Contingency Plan dated June 17, 2003 and has been prepared for the Ochoa Industrial Sales Corp. facilities located at West Gate Industrial Park, Road 869, Km.0.3,  Bo. Palmas, Cata?o, Puerto Rico.

2.0 Purpose

This contingency plan has been designed to minimize hazards to human health or the environment resulting from fires, explosions, or any unplanned sudden or non-sudden release of hazardous waste/materials or any of its constituents to the air, soil or surface water. The provisions of this plan will be carried out imm

ediately whenever there is a fire, explosion or release of hazardous waste/materials or any of its constituents which could threaten human health or the environment.

3.0  General Facility Information

This Contingency Plan has been prepared for the the Ochoa      Industrial     Sales Corp. facilities located at West Gate Industrial Park, Road 869, Km.0.3,     Bo. Palmas, Cata?o, Puerto Rico.

The main activity carried out by the company is the distribution of chemical substances and related materials. These materials are stored in two main areas, a closed warehouse and an open area on the backside of the facility. A drawing illustrating the facilities layout is included as Figure I.

4.0 Emergency Coordinators

At all times, there will be at least one employee either on the facility premises or on call with the responsibility for coordinating all emergency response measures related to the events covered herein.
In the case an emergency situation that requires the activation of this plan arises, the discoverer shall contact an Emergency Coordinator listed on Table I.

Mr. Bernardo Gonzalez, Primary Emergency Coordinator, should be contacted first. In case she is not available, the following person in the list should be addressed. In any case, the order of the persons appearing on the list will be strictly followed for this notification process until someone is reached. The Primary Emergency Coordinator and alternates shall have complete authority to commit company resources in the event of an emergency.

Table II provides a list of organizations or agencies which may be contacted by the Emergency Coordinators in case of an emergency.




5.0    Emergency Procedures and Implementation

The decision to implement the Contingency Plan depends upon whether or not an imminent or actual incident could threaten human health or the environment.

The purpose of this section is to provide a guide to the Emergency Coordinator in making a decision to implement the plan, by providin

g basic decision making criteria.

The Contingency Plan will be implemented in the following situations:

a)    Fire and/or Explosion
    i)    When the fire and/or explosion will cause the release of toxic fumes.
ii) When the fire spreads and could possibly ignite materials at other locations on site or could cause
                        heat-induced explosions.
    iii)    When the fire could possibly spread to offsite areas.
    iv)    When the use of water or water and chemical fire suppressants could result in contaminated     runoff.
v)    When an imminent danger exists that an explosion could occur, causing a safety hazard due to lying fragments or shock waves.
vi)    When an imminent danger exists that an explosion could ignite other materials in the surrounding areas.
vii)    When an imminent danger exists that an explosion could result in the release of a toxic material.
Whenever an explosion occurs.

b)    Spills or Release of Materials
i)    When the spill could result in a release of flammable liquids or vapors, thus causing a fire or explosion hazard.
ii)    When the spill could cause the release of toxic liquids or fumes.
iii)    When although the spill can be contained in site, the potential for ground water contamination still exists.
iv)    When the spill cannot be contained on site, resulting in offsite soil contamination and/or ground or surface water contamination.

6.0    Emergency Response Procedures (Countermeasure Action Plan)

6.1    Alert Procedures

Upon observation of situation that will require the plan to be implemented (refer to section 5.0), the person making the discovery shall immediately, only if within his or her capabilities, perform the tasks outlined in the following standard operating procedure:
a)  Proceed to evaluate the incident for fire and/or explosion, safety and health hazards.
b)  If the incident is due to a spill, stop the flow of the material if possible (only trained personnel refer to Section 21.0).
c)  Immediately notify the Emergency Coordinators appearing on T

able I.

Once a designated Emergency Coordinator has been notified, he or she will initiate the response efforts only if these are within the response capabilities of the response team. The material should be contained immediately to prevent it from reaching areas such as water supply systems, sewers and private property. After containment, the material will be cleaned up (only trained personnel) and disposed of properly.




Once the necessary information has been collected, the communication of the spill to the responsible agencies will be initiated, if applicable and only by personnel authorized to perform these duties.

If the spill or incident is beyond the capabilities of the internal response team, then the Emergency Coordinator will order evacuation of the premises if necessary and will contact a trained emergency response agency or, qualified HAZMAT contractor.

6.2    Action Procedures

This plan will be activated upon the occurrence of any spill related to the storage, usage or handling of hazardous materials at any time within the company's premises. Appropriate actions will begin as indicated on Section 6.0 of this plan.

Primary responsibility for supervision of control, containment and clean-up rests with the highest ranking company employee on site, until properly relieved of control, either by the Emergency Coordinator, a company official or a responsible agency official or duly appointed on-scene coordinator. During any incident, the chain of command must be followed in the form of the Incident Command System (ICS).

7.0 Notification

In the event of an imminent or actual emergency situation, the Emergency Coordinator will be notified first; subsequently, all emergency response personnel, appropriate agencies, and if their help is needed, civil defense, fire or police departments will also be notified. Authorization to contact
regulatory agencies regarding any spill, will be limited to the following personnel, who must be contacted as soon as possible

:

a)   Mr. Bernardo Gonzalez - Primary Emergency Coordinator

If the above coordinator can not be reached within a reasonable time, the person in charge  will contact Hector Berrrios , Facilities Maintenance Supervisor and Alternate Emergency Coordinator.

8.0 Identification of the Material

The Emergency Coordinator or person in charge will immediately identify the character, exact source, amount and extent of the release. The initial identification will be performed by visual inspection of the material and location of the release. For this purpose, all materials must always be properly identified and labeled and its location shall always be the same.

9.0    Assessment of the Release

The Emergency Coordinator will assess possible hazards, both direct and indirect to human health or the environment that may result from the release, fire or explosion as well as a determination of whether the release is within the capabilities of the internal response team.

The safety of the personnel at the scene of a release of hazardous materials is critical to consider before any action is taken. All release of materials should be considered initially as extremely hazardous until the identity of the spilled material is known. If for any reason, the identity of the material is not clear or cannot be determined, use all necessary precautions, such as personal protective equipment and secure the area from unauthorized access. Never approach the area of a spill by yourself or without notifying your supervisor. The person accompanying the person doing the assessment or control work must be equally protected and trained to handle the emergency. 
The following guidelines must be followed as part of the initial response:

a)    Use of Level B PPE (SCBA or supplied airline respirators) is mandatory for the initial entry. After atmospheric hazard evaluation is completed, lower PPE's could be selected but only as indicated by the Emergency Coordinator in charge.
b)        The use of the buddy

system (work in pairs) is also mandatory.

In addition the following precautions should be taken:

a)    Approach the spill from its upwind side.
b)    Do not touch the material and avoid any direct or indirect contact with it.
c)    Remove all possible ignition sources from the immediate area.
d)    Do not allow smoking in the area.
e)    Limit the access to the area to response personnel only.
f)    Do not touch any container, tank or material unless full knowledge of the hazards involved is     available.

If unidentified fuming liquids or gases are present do not approach.

If the material cannot be identified, note the source of the spill and observe any visible physical properties such as color, odor, reaction with other materials, flammability, reactivity, corrosivity, irritability, symptoms on affected persons or hazards created.

Once the spilled material is identified, the following standard operating procedure should be followed:
i)      Determine what type of container is damaged (i.e.; drums, tank truck, etc.),    determine also the amount of damaged containers and the extent (which are damaged and which are not).

ii)    If appropriate, take samples of the spilled material for chemical testing  and further identification or confirmation of initial determination.


iii)    Obtain Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) or statement of hazards in     order to determine emergency procedures and precautions and fire fighting procedures and precautions. If mixed loads of materials are involved, further assessment of the measures may be needed.

Once the identity of the material released has been established, the assessment of the release magnitude and human danger potential must be established.

For this purpose the following references will be used:
a)    NIOSH Pocket Guide to Chemical Hazards
b)    DOT Emergency Response Guidebook

These documents will be available through the Emergency Coordinator and are limited to the use by trained personnel only.

Once the Emergency Coordinator determine

s that a release, fire or explosion that could threaten human health and/or the environment has occurred, he/she will proceed as established in the following standard operating procedure:

i)    If the initial assessment indicates that evacuation of local areas may be advisable, the proper authorities must be advised immediately. The Emergency Coordinator must be available to help officials decide whether local areas should be evacuated.
ii)    The Emergency Coordinator must immediately notify either the government official designated as the On-Scene Coordinator for that geographical area or the National Response Center.

A decontamination area will be established near any release area. Any decontamination procedure must be carried out at an area properly isolated by impervious materials. A typical decontamination area is described in Figure II. Also the location of this DECON area appears in a drawing included as Figure IV. In order to avoid cross contamination during the cleaning process, the area being decontaminated will be isolated by means of tarpaulins resistant to mild acids and organic solvents. The tarpaulins will prevent excursions of dust and mist outside of the clean-up area, including walls. A sand bag barrier dike, faced with absorbent material will be placed around the area to be decontaminated as well as the decontamination area. Once clean-up is completed, dike material will be collected and disposed of properly.

Any standing water or liquid remaining at a hazardous material release area, will be removed using absorbent material. Used absorbent material will be deposited in containers and later disposed of properly.

Prior to leaving a hazardous material release location undergoing decontamination, decontamination of personal protective clothing will be conducted by removing all bulk material from overboots and all outside protective clothing materials as well as exposed skin surfaces. All personnel involved in the clean-up operations will thoroughly cl

ean-up by spraying, washing and scrubbing with a soft bristle, non-metallic brush, a mild detergent solution, and rinse three times all outside protective clothing materials as well as exposed skin surfaces at the decontamination area prior to departure from the site.

All rinse waters and personnel decontamination wash waters will be collected in suitable containers for later disposal at an approved facility.

Should any pump and/or line be used for transfer of liquids to shipping containers it must be dismantled, drained and scrubbed with a hard bristle non-metallic brush suitable for the determined atmospheric hazard, washed with detergent, steam cleaned and tripled rinsed with water.

After the decontamination process is completed, each decontaminated unit or equipment will be rinsed with water for a final time. The wash water must be collected in appropriate containers for later disposal. After this is performed, each unit will be tagged as ready for later use.

10.0    Control Procedures

As mentioned before, potential accidents fall under two general classifications:

1.    Fire and/or explosions

The hazardous materials storage area can be easily accessed by fire fighting and other emergency vehicles and equipment.

An outside contractor Emergency Response Team will be called in during a major emergency. During times of extended power failure or severe weather, fire protection personnel will be placed on alert to protect personnel and property.

If a fire should develop, notification will be given immediately to the local fire department. Efforts may be concentrated on preventing the fire from spreading to nearby areas. The fire fighting efforts will be limited to incipient fires only, and to the use of fire extinguisher, and will be carried out by the Emergency Response Team until outside assistance arrives.


The following procedures will be followed in the areas affected by a fire or explosion:

i) Fire doors in buildings will be closed. Caution, if you detect

a warm door, and you suspect a fire, do not open the door. 
ii) Hazardous work, or work with hazardous materials, in all affected areas will be stopped immediately.
iii)    All feed lines and additional equipment will be shut down and monitored for leaks, pressure build up, gas generation, ruptures in valves, pipes or equipment.
iv)     The Emergency Coordinator will be contacted.
v)    The area will be cleared of all personnel not actively involved in fighting the fire. These persons are to report to the designated rally points for accountability. Rally points are shown in Figure Ill.

All injured persons will be removed, and medical treatment will be administered by qualified personnel (First Aid and/or CPR can only be administered by certified individuals).

Because fire is always a potential hazard in spills of flammable materials, possible sources of ignition will be eliminated. Vehicular traffic and hazardous work in the area will cease until the spill is contained and safety is restored. If spilled materials are flammable, the Emergency Response Team will mobilize with foam equipment and hoses. Flushing with large quantities of water or foaming will be performed only if advised by the Emergency Coordinator.

If a highly flammable material (flammable gas) is released, all persons within at least a quarter mile radius from the facility will be notified. In the event of an imminent or actual emergency situation, the Emergency Coordinator will be the person to issue the notification, and if their help is needed, civil defense, fire or police departments will also be notified. Authorization to notify will be limited to the following personnel, who must be contacted as soon as possible:

1)    Mr. Eitel R. Gomez. - President
2)    Mr. Bernardo Gonzalez - Primary Emergency Coordinator

All ignition sources within the area will be eliminated. Use of motor vehicles within the area will be restricted or eliminated to avoid ignition of the vapor, which can cause a flashback to the

source and an initial explosion or fire of significant magnitude. If the chances of an impending explosion are high, the entire area within a 2000 ft. radius of the source will be evacuated.

If a fire at or near hazardous materials is involved and is concentrated at the source, people will be evacuated up to a half mile downwind.

Fire fighting will not be done at the risk of injury to the persons involved; however, early containment of fires can significantly decrease total damage.

The internal communication system will not be used, unless absolutely necessary so that it remains dedicated to handle emergency calls only.

Area evacuation will be necessary in case of major fire or explosion. Specifics are outlined under general evacuation procedures (Section 17.0). All personnel must be trained in evacuation procedures and proper routes of exit from their respective work areas.

Until evacuation is ordered, personnel who are not in an affected area will stay in their respective work areas. Contract personnel and visitors will be cleared form the area and instructed to report to a guard house or office area.

The Emergency Coordinator will be responsible for all fire fighting efforts until outside help arrives. The Emergency Coordinator is always the lead shift foreman or senior person present, until a higher rank official or agency representative arrives.

Supervisor's of unaffected areas will stay with their personnel and be ready to evacuate and account for the persons under their supervision.

An "all clear" signal will be given when the fire has been extinguished and the safety of personnel is no longer endangered. The Emergency Coordinator will determine when the emergency has concluded and consult with higher ranking officials before the signal is given. All emergency equipment used must be cleaned and fit for use prior to resumption of operations in the affected areas.

2.  Spills or material release

In the event of a major emergency involving a material sp

ill or release, the following general procedures will be used for rapid and safe response and control of the situation. Emergency contacts found in Table II, provide a quick reference guideline to follow in the event of a major spill. If an employee discovers a chemical spill or process upset resulting in a vapor release, he or she will immediately report it to the area supervisor.

The area supervisor will contact the designated Emergency Coordinator at the time of the incident. When contacted, the designated Emergency Coordinator will proceed as follows:

i)    Identify the material spilled or released.
ii)    Identify location of the release or spillage of the hazardous material.
iii)    Estimate the amount released and the rate at which it ,is being released.
iv)    Determine the direction in which the spill or vapor or fume release is heading.
v)    Determine if there are any injured persons.
vi)    Determine the possibility of a fire and/or explosion.
vii)    Determine the area and materials involved and the intensity of the possible fire and/or explosion.

This information will help the Emergency Coordinator to assess the magnitude and potential seriousness of the spill or release. If the incident is determined to lie within the capabilities of the internal response team, the Emergency Coordinator will deploy the necessary personnel. If the incident is beyond the capabilities of the internal team, then the Emergency Coordinator will contact the appropriate external contractors or agencies.

The intent of any initial response effort will be to protect human health and safety, and then the environment. Identification, containment, treatment and disposal will then become the secondary response.

In the event of a leak or spill, a contractor will be summoned to remove any standing liquids and haul the material to a facility approved to handle such materials.

If for some reason the spill is not contained within a dike or sump area, an area of isolation will be established around the

spill. The size of the area will generally depend on the size of the spill and the characteristics of the materials involved. If the spill is large and involves the rupture of a tank or pipeline, an initial isolation of at least 100 ft. in all directions will be established to allow clean-up and repair and to prevent exposure. When any spill occurs, only those persons involved in overseeing or performing emergency operations will be allowed within the designated hazard area. If possible, the area will be roped, taped or otherwise blocked off and properly posted to indicate the hazards present.

If the spill results in the release of a toxic vapor or fume cloud, further evacuation will be enforced. An area of at least 500 ft. wide and 1000 ft. long will be evacuated downwind of where volatile materials are spilled.

Because winds in the area tend to vary, the quickest and most accurate assessment is through the installation of a wind sox. When this is not feasible, the Weather Service can be contacted at 791-0376 or the Luis Munoz Marin International Airport can be contacted at 791-6153 for accurate wind conditions.


The Puerto Rico Environmental Quality Board and the National Response Center will be notified whenever one of the following situations occur:

i)    A spill discharges to a surface water and the quantity of hazardous material is equal to or greater than the Reportable Quantity specified under 40 CFR Part 117.
ii)    One thousand gallons or more of oil are spilled in a single event. If a lesser quantity has been spilled, but has entered a storm sewer, it is advisable to contact local authorities for assistance or if it is not possible to intercept the spill at the outfall or prevent the oil slick from moving.
iii)    The spill involves other hazardous materials not listed but used at the facilities, if they pose an actual or potential hazard to life or property.

If the Emergency Coordinator determines that the company is unable to handle the emergency, the local

, state, and federal authorities will be notified of the situation. Evacuation of all affected areas will begin as soon as possible.

Most materials spills and leaks are contained within the dikes and sump provided in the backyard area. Small spills occurring in a diked area are flushed with plenty of water to the sump provided in that area. The area is dried using absorbent material. All disposable PPE and absorbing material used will be disposed of properly.

For all large spills or serious leaks the following guidelines will be followed as closely as possible. These are only general guidelines and actual circumstances may dictate that certain alterations be made to these procedures:

i)    If a leak develops or a spill occurs, the person discovering the discharge will immediately contact the Emergency Coordinator. The Emergency Coordinator will obtain the following information:
a)    Person(s) injured, if any, and seriousness of injuries.
b)    Location of the spill or leak, material involved, and source.
c)    The approximate amount spilled, an estimate of the liquid and/or gas discharge rate, and the direction the liquid flow or gaseous cloud is moving.
d)    Whether or not a fire is involved.

Next, the Emergency Coordinator will:

a)    Initiate evacuation of the hazard area.
b)    Initially isolate least 100 ft. in all directions and keep all persons upwind of spill.
c)    Obtain medical attention for any injured persons. It may be helpful to instruct the caller in initial first aid procedures. Then call the local hospitals.
d)    Call the local fire department if a fire is involved that cannot be extinguished by facility personnel. Fight small fires with dry chemicals, C02 or foam, and large fires with water jetspray, fog, or foam. Keep heat exposed containers cooled with water spray and remove them from the fire if possible. If a rising sound comes from a venting device or container begins to discolor, withdraw immediately from the area.
e)    Dispatch emergency personnel to the site t

o take the appropriate action.
f)    Contact the proper authorities if the spill or release is large. Contact local authorities first so that, if necessary, downstream water users and/or persons downwind of the fumes can be notified and, if needed, evacuated. If a large spill occurs, the initial evacuation area downwind should be at least 500 ft. long.

iii)    Cleanup personnel will:

a)    Make sure all unnecessary persons are removed from the hazard area.
b)    Put on PPE's.
c)    If flammable material is involved, remove all ignition sources, and use spark and explosion proof equipment suitable for the atmospheric conditions present.
d)    If possible, try to stop the leak. Special tools and materials should be kept on hand for temporary repairs.
e)    Remove all surrounding materials that could be specially reactive with materials in the spill. Determine the major components in the material at the time of the spill.
f)    Use absorbent pads, booms, soil, sandbags, sand and other inert materials to contain divert and clean up the spill if it has not been contained by a dike or sump. Most spills contained in dikes or sumps can be pumped back into the appropriate container for later disposal.
g)    If the spill reaches a storm sewer, try to isolate the discharge by using sand, soil, sandbags, etc. If this is done, dilute materials in the storm sewer with large quantities of water and pump this material out into a temporary holding tank or drums as soon as possible. If a spill enters a storm drain, use absorbent booms and sweeps around the drain to contain and absorb materials that float or that are water insoluble.
h)    Place all containment and cleanup materials in approved DOT containers for proper disposal. Some items, such as absorbent pads, rags and booms may have to be cut.
i)    Place all recovered liquids, wastes and contaminated solids in approved DOT containers for removal to an approved facility.

If an amount of material, equal or in excess, of the Reportable Quantity spills into unp

rotected ground so that underground water could be contaminated, the Puerto Rico Department of Natural Resources and the Environment will be notified before any action to protect the groundwater is conducted.

All emergency equipment used in the incident must be cleaned and fit for use prior to resumption of operations in the affected areas.

11.0            Prevention of Recurrence or Spread of Fires, Explosions or Releases

Actions to prevent the recurrence or spread of fires, explosions or releases include stopping processes and operations, collecting and containing released material, and recovering or isolating containers. In addition, if the facility stops operations in response to an emergency, the Emergency Coordinator will monitor valves, pipes and other equipment for leaks, pressure build up, gas generation or ruptures.

12.0            Storage and Treatment of Released Materials

Immediately after the emergency, the Emergency Coordinator will make arrangements for treatment, storage, or disposal of recovered material, contaminated soil, surface water, or any other contaminated material.

13.0            Incompatible Wastes

The Emergency Coordinator will ensure that any material waste which may be incompatible with the released material is isolated, treated, stored and disposed of until cleanup procedures are completed.

14.0           Post Emergency Equipment Maintenance
After an emergency incident, all emergency equipment listed in Section 15.0 will be cleaned so that it is fit for use or it will be replaced. Before operations are resumed an inspection of all safety equipment will be conducted.

17.0            Evacuation Plan

All emergencies require prompt and deliberate action. In the event of any major emergency, it will be necessary to follow an established set of procedures. Such established procedures will be followed as closely as possible, however, in spe

cific emergency situations, the Emergency Coordinator may deviate from the procedures to provide a more effective plan for bringing the situation under control. The Emergency Coordinator is responsible for determining which emergency situations require facility evacuation.

The company employs a warning system, integral to the intercom, to initiate the evacuation of all areas. In addition to the alarm, the internal telephone system is used to notify key personnel as to the nature of the emergency and the recommended plan of action. Total facility evacuation is initiated only by an Emergency Coordinator.

In the event a facility evacuation is imminent, the following actions will be taken:
i)    The warning for evacuation will be activated.
ii)    Gates will be opened immediately. No further entry to visitors, contractors, or trucks will be permitted. All vehicle traffic within the facilities will cease to allow safe exit of personnel and movement of emergency equipment.
All personnel, visitors, and contractors will immediately leave through the exit gate and proceed to assigned rally points. (See Figure III)

iv)    No person shall remain in or reenter the location unless specifically authorized by the person or persons calling for the evacuation. In allowing this, the person in charge assumes the responsibility for those persons within the perimeter. Those within the fenced area will normally include Emergency Response Team personnel or emergency teams.
v)    All persons will be accounted for by their immediate supervisors. Supervisors will designate the safest exits for their employees and will also choose alternate exits in case the first choice is inaccessible. To assist in this endeavor, the Emergency Coordinator will use the internal telephone system to call the area supervisor, to inform him or her about the nature of the emergency.
vi)    During exit, the supervisor should try to keep his or her group together. Rally points for specific areas are shown in Figure III. Immedi

ately upon exit through the gate, the highest ranking supervisor will prepare a list of all personnel at the exit gate. All other personnel who have persons reporting to them should report immediately to the front gate for final accounting.
vii)    Upon completion of the employee list, the supervisor in charge will hand carry the list to the Emergency Coordinator. All other personnel will remain at their assigned rally point area. viii)    Contract personnel should also be listed with the name of their company. Contract foremen should report to the front gate. ix)    The names of Emergency Response team and or other emergency team members involved in the emergency response efforts will be reported, in writing, to the front gate by designated response team personnel.
x)    A final tally of persons will be made by the Emergency Coordinator.
xi)    No attempt to find persons not accounted for will involve endangering lives of others by reentry into emergency areas. xii)    Reentry into the fenced area will be made only after clearance is given by the Emergency Coordinator. At his/her direction, a signal or other notification will be given for reentry into the facility.
xiii)    In all questions of accountability, immediate supervisors will be held responsible for those persons reporting to them. Visitors will be the responsibility of those employees they are seeing. Contractors are the responsibility of those persons administering the individual contracts. Truck drivers are the responsibility of the warehouse supervisor or the area supervisor where the truck is loading/unloading.
xiv)    Drills will be held to practice all of these procedures and will be treated with the same seriousness as an actual emergency.

18.0    Required Reports

As required under 40 CFR Part 265.56 G) any emergency event that requires implementing the contingency plan will be reported in writing within 15 days to the EPA Regional Administrator. A reporting SOP for emergency events is shown in Figure V.

Prior to submitt

ing any written report to any government agency, the Emergency Coordinator shall insure that a copy is forwarded to the Management for review and approval.

In addition to these reporting requirements for state and federal authorities, internal reporting requirements shall be met. The following incidents require notification within 24 hours in the form of a written report.

This report will be filed and shall be used for further incident response evaluation. The incidents are:

a)    All fires.
b) Unusual gas or vapor releases.
c) Chemical spills of more than 1 gallon (or smaller volumes if highly toxic materials are involved).
d)    All injuries, including minor cuts and bruises, all burns and chemical irritations.
e)    All equipment damage due to malfunction or operating error. f)All "near misses" of the above variety that could have had serious consequences.

19.0    Amendments to the Contingency Plan

The contingency plan will be reviewed annually, and immediately amended, if needed, whenever:

a)       There are revisions to applicable federal, state or local regulations.  

b)    The plan fails in a drill or emergency.

c)    The facility changes in its design, construction, operation, maintenance, or other circumstances in a way that materially alters the potential for fires, explosions, or releases of, hazardous materials or hazardous material constituents, or changes in the response necessary in any emergency.

d)    The list of Emergency Coordinators change.
e)    The list of emergency equipment changes.
f)    An environmental permit is revised.

20.0    Inspection Requirements

The hazardous materials storage facilities are inspected on a weekly basis. The inspection forms include a written checklist to be followed during the inspection. The facilities are inspected for signs posted, safety features, liquid level, tank or container identification, ruptures, corrosion, leaks, conditions of vents, integrity of dikes, materials inside dikes and other. Any deficiency is immediately reported

, and corrective action taken as soon as possible.

Whenever a tank truck is cleaned inside, before being placed in service, a visual inspection shall be made. If evidence of corrosion or damage is noted, a non-destructive thickness test shall be made on tank heads and shell bodies. The results of the tests will be compared with records maintained at the facility.

Records are maintained until the next internal inspection is conducted or five years, whichever is longest.
All fire extinguisher must comply with National Fire Code Standards for portable fire extinguisher, and they must be inspected after each use or at least once every month.

Equipment for use in containing and cleaning up spilled hazardous materials are inspected after each use, or at least once every week.

Records of these inspections shall be kept for at least three years.


21.0    Personnel Training

Prior to any company employee being assigned to handling hazardous materials, substances or waste, he or she must be instructed by qualified resources, on the hazards of the material, substance or waste, safety and health precautions, and the use and requirements for protective clothing and equipment, including respirators.
Any operational personnel that will be involved in any way in the response to an incident involving hazardous materials, waste or substances must receive the appropriate training.

The following trainings shall be taken by the appropriate personnel:

a) 24 hour Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (First Responder Operations Level Course) Personnel that will help in the control of the incident but that will not apply defensive measures to control the spill. 

b) 40 hour Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (Hazardous Materials Technician Course) Personnel that will actually become in contact with the spilled material and that will employ defensive strategies in order to stop the release. The Emergency Coordinators must have at least this course level.

c) F

ire Fighting Training 
d) Employees that are part of the fire brigade or fire fighting team. 

e) CPR and First Aid
            Recommended for all employees involved in the response to an  incident.
f) 8 hour HAZWOPER Refresher
g) All employees that are part of the Emergency Response Team must    comply with the yearly continuing education requirement as established by OSHA.

STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURE FOR REPORTING OF EMERGENCY EVENTS 

This SOP will be followed in any case that a report related to any emergency covered by this plan must be issued to any regulatory agency.

1.    Once the extent of the situation has been assessed and an Emergency Coordinator has been appointed, he/she will contact the pertinent regulatory agency as per the following requirements:

a)    In the event of a transportation related incident the DOT must be contacted at 1-202-426-1830.
b)    In the event of an accidental or intentional release of a hazardous substance in excess of its Reportable 
           Quantity the US Coast Guard National Response Center (NRC) must be contacted at 1-800-424-8802.

2.    The caller must have the following information that will be given to the party responding to the call:

a)    His/her name, position and complete name and address of the facility.
b)    He/she must state that the notification is being given in compliance with reporting requirements established by law. c)    State the approximate amount of the spill and the identity of the material.
d)    The date and approximate time in which the spill ocurred. e)    Determination of wether the spill is moving or not outside of the property boundaries.
f)    Determination of injured personnel.
g)    An estimate of the property damage already sustained.
h)    Wind direction and speed.
i)    General weather conditions.
j)    Wether the spilled material will reach neighboring bodies of water.
k)    Probable cause of the spill.
I)    Cleanup procedures being implemented, if any.
m)    Regulatory agencies contacted.

3.    In addition to the notification requirements stated above wether the material has exceeded the RQ's published or not, the Emergency Coordinator will contact the following regulatory agencies:

a)    United States Environmental Protection Agency, Caribbean Field Office (USEPA, C

FO) at 725-7825.
b)    Puerto Rico Environmental Quality Board at 767-8181.
c)    United States Coast Guard at 722-2943.
d)    Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority (PRASA) at 7662650.

As required under 40 CFR Part 265.560), any emergency event that requires the implementation of this Contingency Plan will be reported in writing by certified mail return receipt within 15 days to the EPA Regional Administrator.
